rename.from: Onedrive token cannot be read (headless setup)
rename.to: Onedrive token cannot be read (headless setup): Couldn't decode response: invalid character 'e' looking for beginning of value

body:
> The token can successfully be generated on the device with browser and it can be copied at full length in the headless device's terminal.

You need to copy the result of  `rclone authorize "onedrive" "XXX"` not the actual token - are you doing that?

I tried this flow here and it worked fine for me.

This seems similar to #8323 - you could use the commands in that issue to check the output from `rclone authorize` is a base64 encoded token.

This might be relevant also #5835

> Configuring rclone with Onedrive Personal

Why are you supplying tenant? I didn't think that was needed for onedrive personal.

> > The token can successfully be generated on the device with browser and it can be copied at full length in the headless device's terminal.
> 
> You need to copy the result of `rclone authorize "onedrive" "XXX"` not the actual token - are you doing that?

I'm copying the actual token between the "paste the following into your remote machine" remarks... see below


```

2025/07/25 22:30:24 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.70.3" finishing with parameters ["rclone" "authorize" "onedrive" "eyJjbGllbnRfaWQiOiI2MmJmMxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx" "-vv"]

> This seems similar to [#8323](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/8323) - you could use the commands in that issue to check the output from `rclone authorize` is a base64 encoded token.

The output is valid BASE64.
And it looks like JSON, I wonder though if the escaping is intended:

```json
{"token":"{\"access_token\":\"eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJub25jZSI6IlgwNFZFaUkwe....HIdVyaufhrFQ\",\"token_type\":\"Bearer\",\"refresh_token\":\"1.AXkAewi8KVI_....ihA\",\"expiry\":\"2025-07-25T23:46:30.2877933+02:00\",\"expires_in\":3888}"}
```

Anyway the contained access_token is also valid - I checked with jwt.io.

Using `rclone authorize "onedrive"` and `rclone authorize "onedrive" "ey...."` is a difference.
I don't want to use the "rclone predefined" (shared) client_id. I'm not an expert on OAUTH2 but in the former case the browser asks me to log in and then a consent screen shows up. With the latter command the browser directly shows a "success" screen.

> This might be relevant also [#5835](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/5835)

I don't see any references to that issue in the logs.

> Why are you supplying tenant? I didn't think that was needed for onedrive personal.

client_credentials flow. It says it is needed for that.

I also tried to base64 decode the `rclone authorize` response... reformat the json to this

```json
{
    "token": {
        "access_token":"ey...",
        "token_type":"Bearer",
        "refresh_token":"1.AXk...",
        "expiry":"2025-07-26T00:15:40.8660275+02:00",
        "expires_in":4623
    }
}
```

...and reencoding it as base64.

Unfortunately same issue:

```
2025/07/25 21:04:31 DEBUG : onedrive_personal_rs: config out: out=&{State:*oauth-authorize,choose_type,, Option:<nil> OAuth:<nil> Error:Couldn't decode response - try again (make sure you are using a matching version of rclone on both sides: invalid character 'e' looking for beginning of value
 Result:}, err=<nil>
Couldn't decode response - try again (make sure you are using a matching version of rclone on both sides: invalid character 'e' looking for beginning of value


2025/07/25 21:04:31 DEBUG : onedrive_personal_rs: config in: state="*oauth-authorize,choose_type,,", result=""

Error: failed to configure OneDrive: empty token found - please run "rclone config reconnect onedrive_personal_rs:"
```

Something that just catched my eye but shouldn't be relevant for the current issue

```
2025/07/25 22:30:19 DEBUG : Redirecting browser to: https://login.microsoftonline.com/<MY-TENANT-ID>/oauth2/v2.0/authorize?access_type=offline&client_id=<MY-CLIENT-ID>&redirect_uri=http%3A%2F%2Flocalhost%3A53682%2F&response_type=code&scope=Files.Read+Files.ReadWrite+Files.Read.All+Files.ReadWrite.All+Sites.Read.All+offline_access&state=n93yWxq7y8DzzzzhHm9F7
```

The app should not request `Sites.Read.All`. 

The documentation says:
> The Sites.Read.All permission is required if you need to [search SharePoint sites when configuring the remote](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/pull/5883). However, if that permission is not assigned, you need to exclude Sites.Read.All from your access scopes or set disable_site_permission option to true in the advanced options.

I'll try to update the config before doing the authorization step. If it changes anything (not expected!) I'll report back.

I set scopes through advanced config (option 3 when asked for access scopes).
As expected it has no influence on the token decoding issue.

oauthutil.go

```go
case "*oauth-authorize":
        // Read the updates to the config
	outM := configmap.Simple{}
	token := oauth2.Token{}
	code := in.Result
	newFormat := true
	err := outM.Decode(code)
	if err != nil {
		newFormat = false
		err = json.Unmarshal([]byte(code), &token) // <-- expects json, presumably "{" but finds "ey..."
	}
	if err != nil {
	    return fs.ConfigError(newState("*oauth-authorize"), fmt.Sprintf("Couldn't decode response - try again (make sure you are using a matching version of rclone on both sides: %v\n", err))
	}
```

Not sure how this is supposed to work with what I am seeing as output of `rclone authorize onedrive ey...`.

Output (see also above):

```
Paste the following into your remote machine --->
ey...SUPERLONGTOKENHERE...
<---End paste
2025/07/25 22:30:24 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.70.3" finishing with parameters ["rclone" "authorize" "onedrive" "eyJjbGllbnRfaWQiOiI2MmJmMxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx" "-vv"]
```

The output starts with "ey..." but is not a standard JWT token.
No `header.payload.signature` structure with 3 base64 encoded parts. Instead its ONE BIG string and it can be base64 decoded in its entirety. 

But even if id would be base64decoded beforehand the result is still no valid json as I pointed out earlier.

```
{"token":"{\"access_token\":\"eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJub25jZSI6IlpGZS05Y2k2ZjFlWms5amlKeHF4SVhzLWRCVElLU3lySDExZ3cxWWdOaEEiLCJhbGciOiJSUzI1NiIsIng1dCI6IkpZaEFjVFBNWl9MWDZEQ...
```

Not sure why this works for others but not for me :(

I am getting this too, my token also starts with ey. If I run it on a machine that has a browser, it is able to authorize fine so I think it is something with the no browser token copy/paste process specifically that is broken.

@calzemelmancvp can you double check that the cut and paste buffer can hold the whole output of `rclone authorize` and that when you paste it in, it is all complete? That has been a problem in the past and might be here.

@ncw Yeah, I saw that might be the issue. I visually inspected what got pasted. I could see that the starting character ("e") was always the same and then what I pasted ended with the same letters I saw at the end on my local PC. Unless it is cutting out the _middle_ of the paste buffer, it looked complete.

By the way, I was able to work around this by:
1. hitting Y at the menu (as if the server had a browser)
2. opening firewall port between the server port and my local IP
3. creating SSH tunnel
4. going to localhost:XYZ on my local PC, having that get tunneled to the server, and completing the authentication 

But I am sure that won't work in all cases.

Thanks for the quick response!

pasted 6020 bytes.
truncated after 4095 bytes.


I still wonder how the pasted part is supposed to work looking at the formatting of the payload but hey... one step after another ;-) Thanks for the build with additional debug logging.

@naymore thanks for confirming it is truncated. I think the error message could be better!

It is base64 encoded to make it easier to cut and paste I think. Also rclone can add extra data to the response which I don't think it is doing here, so it doesn't need to be encoded.

Which terminal are you using and exactly how are you doing the cut and paste? I want to try to replicate here.

Thanks

> Which terminal are you using and exactly how are you doing the cut and paste? I want to try to replicate here.

From the top of my head... good old windows command prompt.
Might as well be Windows Terminal. I'm using both regularly.
Copying = selecting all the characters (left mouse button, drag) followed by a right mouse button click (= copy)

As for the headless system - this is a PuTTy SSH session.
Pasting = right mouse button (= paste)


> It is base64 encoded to make it easier to cut and paste I think. Also rclone can add extra data to the response which I don't think it is doing here, so it doesn't need to be encoded.

I wasn't so much worried about the base64 encoding but the contents of the base64 encoded string. It's no valid JSON if you ask me.

All, getting the same problem: `invalid character 'e' looking for beginning of value`. I have a business onedrive. If you want any help in testing, I would be glad to.

Currently did the work around of forwarding port via local ssh tunnel: `ssh -L 127.0.0.1:53682:127.0.0.1:53682 -vN <host>` this worked alright. 

So something is definitely up with parsing that happens during copy paste.

If you do the copy paste it two parts it should work fine.

Perhaps I need to make that easier to do.
@ncw Copying the token in two parts doesn't make any difference. The problem is not the clipboard. The problem is rclone truncating the input.
